channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Electroshock Therapy for Internet Addicts? China Vows to End It
item.media:description: Students at the Qide Education Center, a military-style boot camp in Beijing for internet addiction, in 2014. Experts welcomed a draft law that would ban abusive treatment at internet detox camps in China.
item.description: The government has drafted a law to ban electroshock and physical punishment at detox camps, where most of the patients are children.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Zhou Youguang, Who Made Writing Chinese as Simple as ABC, Dies at 111
item.media:description: Zhou Youguang in Beijing in 2011. Late in life, he became an outspoken critic of the Chinese government.
item.media:credit: Shiho Fukada for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Zhou created the Pinyin system of Romanized Chinese, which vastly increased literacy in China and eased the agonies of foreigners studying the language.
item.dc:creator: MARGALIT FOX

item.title: A Remarkable Event in El Salvador: A Day Without Murder
item.media:description: Reserve soldiers and National Civil Police officers were arrayed before the news media in San Salvador last year during a push to dismantle gangs.
item.description: The police had no explanation for the pause, which did not last. The killing rate has fallen since a police crackdown began, but gang violence is still rampant.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Cubans Planning to Leave for U.S. Face a Bleak New Reality
item.media:description: Cuban migrants at a shelter in Panama on Friday absorbed the news that the United States had put an end to a policy that allowed Cubans who arrived on American soil without visas to stay.
item.description: Thousands of Cubans who hoped to come to the U.S., including doctors posted abroad, now have to rethink their life plans after a major change in American policy.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BERKELEY COHEN, AZAM AHMED and FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Yellow Fever Outbreak in Brazil Prompts a State of Emergency
item.media:description: Yellow fever vaccinations were being given on Friday in Caratinga, Brazil, to combat an outbreak in Minas Gerais, a southeastern state.
item.description: The outbreak in Minas Gerais State in southeastern Brazil appears to have killed at least 10 people, and 133 suspected cases are being investigated.
item.dc:creator: DOM PHILLIPS

item.title: Trump Team’s Queries About Africa Point to Skepticism About Aid
item.media:description: A rail project by a Chinese construction company in Lagos, Nigeria in 2015. The Trump transition team asks, “How does U.S. business compete with other nations in Africa? Are we losing out to the Chinese?”
item.description: The list of Africa-related questions from the transition staff suggests an American retreat from development and humanitarian goals.
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER
item.category: President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief

item.title: Lagos Slum Was Razed for Its Waterfront, Residents Say
item.media:description: Otodo Gbame, a poor fishing community on the shores of a lagoon in Lagos, was razed by the police and a group of young men, according to residents and local activists, who say the motive was to take the land for development.
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Activists in Otodo Gbame have decried the demolition of the community as an officially sanctioned land grab done at the behest of an influential family.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STEIN

item.title: For Israel, Energy Boom Could Make Friends Out of Enemies
item.media:description: Employees of Noble Energy looked out the window of a helicopter as they flew out last month to the Atwood Advantage, where it is holding its position roughly 40 miles off the coast of Haifa, Israel, above the natural gas well it is drilling.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Once a barren energy island, Israel is finally advancing an ambitious strategy to tap natural gas reserves and transform its place in a hostile region.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Marine Le Pen’s Visit to New York: Trump Tower, Not Trump
item.media:description: Marine Le Pen at Trump Tower in New York on Thursday during a “private trip.” Speculation persisted that a meeting with the president-elect could still take place.
item.media:credit: Kevin Hagen for The New York Times
item.description: A spokesman for Mr. Trump said the president-elect had not met with the French far-right leader, but her stop at Trump Tower clearly wasn’t by chance.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: How Davos Brings the Global Elite Together
item.media:description: For two weeks each January, the population of Davos, Switzerland, swells as the global elite meet for a series of discussions.
item.description: The resort town in the Swiss Alps becomes home to heads of state, captains of industry and others each year during the World Economic Forum.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED and RUSSELL GOLDMAN

item.title: Warsaw Journal: Warsaw Grapples With Gloomy, Gray Smog
item.media:description: A blanket of pollution wreathed Warsaw, above, and dozens of other Polish cities, bringing a global problem more associated with Beijing into the heart of Europe.
item.description: The spike in air pollution was mainly driven by a cold snap that forced thousands of households to crank up poor quality heaters that burn things like coal and garbage.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: France’s Nickname for Kardashian Suspects: Grandpa Robbers
item.media:description: Police officers outside the building where Kim Kardashian West was robbed at gunpoint on Oct. 3 during Paris Fashion Week.
item.description: The older of the 10 suspects were known as Omar the Old and Blue Eyes, according to the newspaper Le Parisien.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: What in the World: Newfoundland Is Big on Bologna: Fried, Stewed and Layered Like a Cake
item.media:description: “The big stick,” a 9.7-pound bologna sausage encased in wax, from Maple Leaf Foods, is a big seller in Newfoundland.
item.media:credit: Antonio de Luca/The New York Times
item.description: A cookbook has 400 recipes for cooking with bologna, but never, its author advises, season it with curry.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Muslim Militants in Philippines Free Hostages Grabbed at Sea
item.description: At least 27 hostages, many of them foreign crewmen, reportedly remain in the hands of different Abu Sayyaf factions.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Despite Protest, Serbia Sends Train to Northern Kosovo
item.media:description: A train left Belgrade, Serbia, on Saturday for Mitrovica in northern Kosovo, where most of Kosovo’s ethnic Serbs live. The Kosovan government objected to the move.
item.description: The train was first to travel from Belgrade, the Serbian capital, to Mitrovica in Kosovo since the 1998-99 Kosovo war.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Codelco Chairman Suffers Minor Injuries After Package Explodes
item.media:description: Chilean police officers at the home of Óscar Landerretche, chairman of the board of the state-owned copper company Codelco, in Santiago on Friday.
item.description: It is unclear why Óscar Landerretche, or the copper company would be a target.
item.dc:creator: PASCALE BONNEFOY

item.title: British Columbia: The ‘Wild West’ of Canadian Political Cash
item.media:description: Christy Clark, the premier of British Columbia, in Vancouver last year.
item.description: British Columbia has no limits on political donations, leading critics to say the provincial government has become a lucrative business dominated by special interests.
item.dc:creator: DAN LEVIN

item.title: Photo of Narendra Modi at the Spinning Wheel Invokes Gandhi, and Some Cry Blasphemy
item.media:description: Mahatma Gandhi with his spinning wheel in 1925.
item.description: The cover of a calendar that usually features the founder of modern India this year had a photo of Prime Minister Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Trilobites: Sometimes Nature is Morbid. That’s Why There’s #BestCarcass.
item.media:description: A frozen fox that was recovered from the Danube River in Germany in December.
item.media:credit: Johannes Stehle/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: A macabre Twitter battle emerged after a group of scientists who study African carnivores starting sharing photos of prey from the field.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: 5-Year-Olds Take School Trip to Reindeer Slaughterhouse, and Outrage Follows
item.media:description: Children in a truck filled with reindeer carcasses, one of several photographs posted on Facebook of a Norwegian school’s trip to a slaughterhouse.
item.description: A school in central Norway found itself deluged by calls after it posted images, some showing carcasses and bloodstained furs, from the children’s visit.
item.dc:creator: HENRIK PRYSER LIBELL

item.title: Erdogan Says Troops Will Be in Cyprus ‘Forever,’ Complicating Hopes of Reuniting
item.media:description: A man on Thursday crossed a United Nations buffer zone that divides an area controlled by Greek Cypriots and one controlled by Turkish Cypriots in Nicosia.
item.description: The Turkish leader, however, often takes a firmer line with domestic audiences than with foreign ones, and diplomats said they remained cautiously optimistic.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ANDREAS RIRIS

item.title: Taiwan Works to Keep Its Central America Friends (Among Its Few)
item.media:description: President Tsai Ing-wen of Taiwan and President Juan Orlando Hernández of Honduras at the presidential palace in Tegucigalpa, the capital of Honduras, on Monday. Taiwan has diplomatic relations with only 20 countries, along with the Vatican; the largest cluster of those is in Latin America and the Caribbean.
item.description: President Tsai Ing-wen is in the region to shore up some of Taiwan’s formal diplomatic relationships as it faces rising pressure from China.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Canada Today: Questioning a Writer’s Ancestry, Bologna Dogs and the Galloping Gourmet
item.media:description: The Canadian author Joseph Boyden at the Edinburgh International Book Festival in Scotland. After nearly three weeks of silence, Mr. Boyden defended his claim to indigenous ancestry this week in two interviews and a news release.
item.media:credit: Russell G Sneddon/Writer Pictures, via Associated Press
item.description: A broad debate about a prominent spokesman for indigenous people, the lowdown on a favorite Newfoundland dish and catching up with Graham Kerr.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Kitsch vs. Antiques: Tourist Trade Threatens Character of London’s Portobello Market
item.media:description: Once an arcade with 200 antique dealers, the World Famous Portobello Market is now an open-plan gallery selling mass-produced souvenirs.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: Hordes of visitors descend on the famous stalls in Notting Hill, but many come for the cheap souvenirs rather than the valuable antiques.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT REYBURN

item.title: Antony Armstrong-Jones, Photographer and Earl of Snowdon, Dies at 86
item.media:description: Antony Armstrong-Jones shooting a film on old age in 1968.
item.description: He married Princess Margaret, the sister of Queen Elizabeth II, in 1960, and plunged into a life of privileges, parties, quarrels and infidelities that ended in divorce 18 years later.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT D. McFADDEN

item.title: A Voice for Indigenous Canadians Defends His Claim to Be One
item.media:description: The Canadian author Joseph Boyden at the Edinburgh International Book Festival in Scotland. After nearly three weeks of silence, Mr. Boyden defended his claim to indigenous ancestry this week in two interviews and a news release.
item.media:credit: Russell G Sneddon/Writer Pictures, via Associated Press
item.description: A report by an indigenous television network in Canada challenged the indigenous ancestry of Joseph Boyden, author of “The Orenda” and other novels.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A Banker Inspired by Western Novelists Seeks to Build Asia
item.media:description: Jin Liqun, 67, head of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, hopes to steer the bank toward building environmentally friendly infrastructure in a way that is free of corruption.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: Jin Liqun, who runs the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, says Faulkner helped him understand complex human relationships.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Chinese State Media Denounce Rex Tillerson’s Call to Block Island Access
item.media:description: Rex W. Tillerson, the nominee for secretary of state, at his Senate confirmation hearing on Wednesday. He said that Beijing’s efforts to build islands in the South China Sea, and to equip some with military equipment, were illegal.
item.description: One newspaper warned of “large-scale war” if the United States intervened in the South China Sea, as Donald J. Trump’s nominee for secretary of state suggested.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Tristram Hunt, Labour Lawmaker, Resigns to Lead V&A Museum
item.media:description: Tristram Hunt in Washington in December. Mr. Hunt has an impressive cultural résumé and has written several books, including a history of the English Civil War.
item.description: The move by Mr. Hunt, a historian and writer who was a critic of his party’s leftist leader, Jeremy Corbyn, will prompt an election in his vulnerable constituency.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Philippine Police Arrest 2 More in September Bombing of Night Market
item.media:description: Mourning the victims of the night-market bombing in Davao City, in the southern Philippines, in September. After the attack, President Rodrigo Duterte declared a regional state of emergency.
item.description: At least seven people had previously been arrested in the Davao City bombing, with the police saying they belonged to the Maute militant group.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Op-Ed Contributors: Twitter Must Do More to Block ISIS
item.media:description: A woman is evacuated from the Bataclan theater after the shooting in Paris on Nov. 13, 2015.
item.description: The militant group uses the platform as a tool of terrorism.
item.dc:creator: ANNE CAMERON CAIN and BEATRIZ GONZALEZ
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Trump’s Pivotal Russian Test
item.media:description: A journalist holds a poster with portraits of President Vladimir Putin, Marine Le Pen and Donald Trump prior to Putin’s annual news conference in Moscow last month.
item.description: Hurtling into a love fest with Putin would be calamitous. Russia responds to toughness and Trump must show it or NATO and the E.U. could unravel.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The U.S. Must Talk to North Korea
item.media:description: The portraits of late North Korean leaders Kim Il-sung and Kim Jong-il in Pyongyang.
item.description: Bilateral diplomacy is the best way for the Trump administration to limit the growing nuclear threat.
item.dc:creator: SIEGFRIED S. HECKER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER
